Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: Cultural Transmission and Phylogenetic Inference in Material Culture
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-four-month research fellowship by Dr. Jonathan Scholnick to work with Dr. Mark Collard at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby, British Columbia.

This project investigates the evolution of cultural traditions in the workshops that produced historical New England gravestones. Many of these artifacts, still standing in burial grounds, are associated with individual carvers through the archival record. The lineages of these gravestone carvers and their workshop affiliations are compared with the decorative techniques to trace the transmission of culture. This study adds to our understanding of the emergence of material culture traditions through social learning of individual craft producers, particularly linking cultural transmission between individuals to population-level cultural traditions. This project will also refine our understanding of material culture diversity of the time-averaged assemblages that archaeologists commonly study.

Recently, biological methods of inferring family trees from an organism's genetic or phenotypic traits have been applied to culture, particularly artifacts and language. Like biology, the aim is to learn about the historic events that account population level cultural diversity, including natural selection, and migration. Since the transmission of cultural behaviors in some ways resembles the way that genes are passed from parent to child, a suite of cultural transmission models have been adapted from population genetics. Culture, however, can be acquired via more diverse and complicated set of pathways. These departures present a challenge to anthropology and other fields that are actively using these cultural evolutionary principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examined the evolution of cultural diversity among historic New England gravestone carvers based on the stylistic and formal variation of the artifacts they produced. These gravestone carvers are known through payments recorded in probate court documents, and signatures of artifacts. Most of the gravestones they carved are preserved in burial grounds throughout Colonial-era towns, and a subset of these gravestones can be directly attributed to individual carvers. I evaluated models of cultural transmission using the decorative attributes of gravestones that are securely attributed to an individual carver.

 

I completed three projects during my 22 months at Simon Fraser University in Canada, and 2 months of fieldwork in Massachusetts. First, I conducted field survey of burial ground sites in eastern Massachusetts in order to develop a database of gravestones that can be attributed to known carvers. Second, analyses of the decorative variation of these artifacts suggest that while carver preferences for dominant decorative motifs were likely shared among peers working at the same time, the more fine-grained decorative features used to execute these designs were shared within workshops, probably passed from master to apprentices. Third, in order to evaluate the broader cultural evolutionary forces that shape decorative motifs, I compared the diversity of decorative motifs found on contemporary gravestones in different villages. The decorative diversity demonstrates that increased numbers of carvers had corresponding effects on stylistic diversity in the gravestone population, although this also lead to increased stylistic divergence in rural areas.

 

This International Research Fellowship project constitutes basic research on the forces and mechanisms of cultural evolution. In particular, this research provides empirical evidence for the processes of innovation, migration, cultural drift, and social learning that shape the cultural repertoires of humans. It provides fine-grained evidence for these processes and individual-level learning strategies among gravestone carvers. More broadly, this research can inform our understanding of how cultural diversity evolves, and is maintained among groups of humans.
